column3: Title
column4: Authors
column8: Inital comment
column9: Second comment
column10: COMMENTS (either add comments here or using the comment function in a given cell. Do not write in the cell itself!)
column13: Number of coauthors from non-academic institutions
column14: Number of coauthors from governmental organizations (USGS, etc)
column15: Forecast spatial scale (point, multipoint, regional, national, global)
column16: If spatial scale is "point" or "multipoint": geographic coordinates from google maps (see notes)
column17: Forecast ecosystem: forest, grassland, freshwater, marine, desert, tundra, atmosphere, agricultural, urban, global, other
column18: Forecast class: biogeochemical or organismal (population or community)
column19: How many forecast variables are discussed in the paper
column24: If specified: more detailed description of model (e.g., Bayesian hierarchical, machine learning, named model (e.g., PROTECH), etc)
column25: Model covariate class(es) used in this study: meteorological, physical, chemical, or biological
column26: Does the paper explicitly identify that random effects were included? (y/n)
column27: Does the paper explicitly talk about latent variables, using this terminology? (y/n)
column32: Are multiple modeling approaches compared (NOT including null models)? (y/n)
column36: What type of null model (e.g. climatology, persistence)
column38: Time step of forecast output (in days)
column39: How often are new forecasts produced (in days)
column41: Model training period mentioned in paper? (y/n)
column43: Iterative forecast (i.e., data updating forecasts iteratively)? (y/n)
column44: What technique of data assimilation? (e.g., KF, enKF, refit, update IC, etc)
column45: Latency of observation data for assimilation (response variable). If not provided, mark "unspecified." Convert units to days
column47: If uncertainty is propagated: Is uncertainty propagation analytic or ensemble-based?
column48: What sources of uncertainty were incorporated?
column56: If at least two categories of uncertainty were partitioned, what was the dominant source of uncertainty?
column57: If the dominant source varies by forecast horizon, season, etc. please describe here
column60: Paper states that forecast was evaluated (y/n)
column61: Forecast evaluation results reported in paper (y/n)
column62: List all skill metrics used (e.g. R2, RMSE, bias, MAE)
column63: Is forecast performance assessed at multiple forecast horizons (results must be reported in paper/supplimental info)? (y/n)
column64: How many forecasting cycles are evaluated/assessed, with the results reported in the paper? (PLEASE READ NOTES HERE)
column65: How many total forecasting cycles are included for that variable in this paper (both those that are evaluated and those that are not)
column66: Maximum forecast horizon such that the forecast is better than the null model (out of any models used). Provide answer in days
column68: Maximum driver latency (latency of the driver with the longest latency). If not specified write "UNK". Provide answer in days
column69: Minimum driver latency (latency of the driver with the shortest latency). If not specified write "UNK". Provide answer in days
column70: Temporal coverage of data used to create this forecasting paper (in days; your best guess is fine here)
column71: Is new data (driver and/or observations) available to the model in real time (<24 hours from collection) without any manual effort when the system is working as intended? (y/n)
column73: Repository in which forecasts are archived
column74: Paper specifies that driver data are publicly available to reproduce the forecasts (according to the paper)
column77: Partnership w/ stakeholder in forecast development mentioned in paper (y/n)
column78: Forecast being used by stakeholder according to paper (y/n)
column79: Type of end user (general public vs institution)

column3: Memory, not just perception, plays an important role in terrestrial mammalian migration
column4: Bracis, C; Mueller, T
column8: Is this actual forecasts or an assessment how well Zebra memory allows them to migrate to a specific location? (e.g. memory mechanisms) I ran this by D, a psychologist who knows a few things about memory and perception and she had MANY thoughts (none very good) about how they approached this.  This is a really interesting case study because it is almost parameterizing the forecast horizon using NDVI data from the past, averaging it over the 2mo, 4mo, and 6mo, time periods, and then making that a momeory mechanism to predict where they would go. It is almost like their forecast model was how we might think of a null model to test how differnet memory times from Zebras could predict their location. So, it is almost like a spatial forecast that really does not have an exact horizon. This is how I read it at least...
column9: yes; annual forecast of zebra migration (No - 2-6 month forecast horizons testing zebra memory)
column25: transformed NDVI, perception, and memory? - yeah, might want to check this one

column3: Implementation of Markov Chains for Probabilistic Forecast of Different Conditions of Moistening in Vegetation Period Based on Example of Voronezh
column4: Akimov, LM
column8: The research has shown the feasibility of using Markov chains to estimate the probability of the occurrence of different conditions of moistening during certain months of the vegetation period. It is really just using existing data at time (t)  to estimate the probability of HTC (hydrothermic coefficient, which uses temperature and precipitation values and is sensitive to dry conditions specific to the climate regime being monitored), which does not appear to be biogeochemical or organismal in nature? It does not appear to really be using any real forecasted data either. Instead, it appears to be gernerating an HTC value and then using a MCMC to
column9: yep!

column3: Brood Surveys and Hunter Observations Used to Predict Gobbling Activity of Wild Turkeys in Mississippi
column4: Palumbo, MD; Vilella, FJ; Strickland, BK; Wang, GM; Godwin, D
column8: i am not sure about this one. i would need to read their methods. also don't know if "turkey gobbling activity" is biogeochemical or organismal?? They say forecast in the abstract but then just have a few predictive models of gobble activity index. None of it is actually using forecasted drivers or generating future predictions w/DA and Uncertatiny partitioning. This is much more like the Ebullition mission where the predictive models were developed posthoc.
column9: not our traditional model of a forecast, but I think it technically counts

column3: Phosphorus and chlorophyll in the Bay of Quinte: A time-series/intervention analysis of 1972-2008 data
column4: Nicholls, KH
column8: forecasting is not the primary focus of the paper, but there is one section where they do forecast P concentrations ~ 8 yrs into the future   RPM: OK - lets evaluuate this. they are looking for regime shifts (step-trends) in the bay and use a AR model to show how predictions of TP (not using forceasted data) maintain stationarity and misrepresent the post P-control time period TP concentraions. Again, they do this using already existing data and nothing forecasted or the AR term alone. So - like many things, I would argue this is not a forecast. I mean, I could do the same thing and use my 2017 ebullition TS model and then in 2018 heat up the sediments, increasing overall ebullition, and show that the AR model from 2017 does not predict ebullition well in 2018 because of this forced step-trend I initialted. So - this to me is a TS approach to show how their management intervention worked. Not a forecast, IMO. Happy to argue. Sorry - I think I am becoming a snobby eco-forecaster and I kind of hate that.
column9: Agree with Nick's comment!

column3: The rice leaf blast simulation model EPIBLAST
column4: KIM, CK; KIM, CH
column8:
Are we planning to include book chapters? This paper describes a model but does very little to actually perform and assess forecasts of it. I wouuld recommned searching for EPIPLAST in scholar or WOS to see if it has been applied to forecast in other papers apart from this book chapter. I am also the one who approved this abstract and I am happy to renege my prior assessment. In text:    After opening the program and listing it, it begins to read daily weather data (MEANING NOT FORECASTED DATA)
(temperature, relative humidity, dew period, wind velocity, and amount of
rainfall) (line 230: GOSUB 1350). ALSO: In the 1992 blast season, we will try to validate and test EPIBLAST in some districts other than Icheon site, based on data from weekly weather forecasts and past weather data. Meanwhile, the model needs further revision to improve the fit with observed disease progress. We are currently attempting to modify the model for developing a panicle blast prediction model by adding some
different variables before and after heading time
